Class com.chimu.form.client.DomainObject_1_AbsClass 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----com.chimu.form.client.DomainObject_1_AbsClass
public abstract class DomainObject_1_AbsClass
extends Object
implements MappedObject, MappedObjectXi
DomainObject_1_AbsClass provides an implementation of FORM oriented functionality for DomainObjects. It implements the MappedObject protocol that FORM requires and also provides a little DomainObject functionality (#copy,#write,#delete). DomainObject_1_AbsClass's implementation uses two instance variables ('oid' and 'isStub') and a default identity slot (also 'oid'). The 'oid' instance variable is just an 'Object' and is completely opaque to this class and FORM. The 'oid' object just has to be able to compare itself (#equals) to another value and return true appropriately. To set the 'oid' slot, this class provides a shorthand method: 'createOidSlotInto_columnName(ObjectMapper mapper, String columnName)'.

There are two constructors for this class: A general 'blank' constructor that subclasses will use to build new domain objects and a FORM specific constructor which only FORM should use when it tries to Replicate a server object. The FORM constructor is the only way to produce an object in the 'isStub' state.

Three remarks about FORM and abstract classes. First, FORM does not require the use of an abstract class: you can have each domain class itself support the "binding" required to interact with FORM. Second, the source to this class is completely under your control: you are licensed to copy this source to you own development directory and modify it to satisfy your needs and standards. You should leave the copyright information within the file if you base it on this one. Third, you can also start from scratch and define you own abstract class as long as it implements the DomainObject interface.

See Also:
DomainObject_1, DomainObject_1_Di, MappedObject

- isStub
This is the (conceptually) simplest implementation of identifying a stub object: use an isStub flag.

The oid provides the real (server) identity of this object.

Variables

- oid 
 protected Object oid
The oid provides the real (server) identity of this object. Oid are only generated, stored, and tested for equality, so they can simply be an Object. Integers work well

- isStub 
 protected boolean isStub
This is the (conceptually) simplest implementation of identifying a stub object: use an isStub flag. This does require constantly managing the flag during stub transitions (where having isStub be derived would not have this property).

form_initState 
 public void form_initState(KeyedArray slotValues)
initState should initialize the state of the object from the slot values and then make sure the object knows it is not a stub object anymore.

Each sublcass should call their parent's initState method before doing their own.

See Also:
form_extractState
form_extractStateInto 
 public void form_extractStateInto(KeyedArray slotValues)
extractState should extract state information from the current object and place it into the slotValues KeyedArray.

Each subclass should call their parent's extractState method before extracting their own state.

See Also:
form_initState
form_forceIdentityFor 
 public boolean form_forceIdentityFor(ObjectMapperXi om)
This should return true if an identity insert was required

form_updateAfterIdentityFor 
 public void form_updateAfterIdentityFor(ObjectMapperXi om)
save 
 public void save()
Note: save() is deprecated. Use write() instead

Save has the same functionality as 'write' currently but is deprecated so save can be used for saving/synching the state of a domain object, which will include deleting if necessary.

write 
 public void write()
Write will either insert or update the object to the database depending on the whether it is a new object or not.

initFrom 
 protected void initFrom(DomainObject_1_AbsClass oldObject)
This method should be called to initialize an object from the values in another object. This is primarily for "#copy"ing objects. Subclasses should call the parents #initFrom(...) before doing their own initialization

(s) configMapper_forDomainObject 
 public static void configMapper_forDomainObject(ObjectMapper mapper)
configMapper_for sets up an already created ObjectMapper with the mapping required for a given class. Each subclass should call the superclass's configMapper_for

All of the general Domain to FORM binding should be specified in root abstract classes so subclasses only have to worry about their own specific functionality.

(s) buildOidSlotInto_columnName 
 protected static void buildOidSlotInto_columnName(ObjectMapper mapper,
                                                   String columnName)
buildOidSlotInto_columnName allows subclasses to specify a particular table column to use for storing the oid object. This method is approximately equivalent to mapper.newDirectSlot("oid",columnName).

If all domain classes used the same identity column (e.g. "id") than this would be unnecessary.

(s) createOidSlotInto_columnName 
 protected static IdentitySlot createOidSlotInto_columnName(ObjectMapper mapper,
                                                            String columnName)
createOidSlotInto_columnName is like buildOidSlot... but it returns the built slot.

(s) linkClass_toMapper 
 public static void linkClass_toMapper(Class aClass,
                                       ObjectMapper newMapper)
Link the class to the mapper supporting the class. This handles the common and simple case where all objects of a single class will belong to the same mapper.
